Review title: A cinematic comedy of gargantuan proportions
Review_body:
It is no sooner than the credits of this holy film have gone from the screen that the viewer realizes that he was witnessed the birth of a new Method. Not that of Brando and De Niro, but the aural force emitted from the acting of this spiritual leader, Bill Murray. A majestic performance of astounding subtlety that brings to mind Orson Welles.As Murray cries: "You're hypocrites! All o'ya!", his demented lament - one of a soul trapped in parallel universes of existence -  leaves us to ponder on the meaning of life itself and what we make of it. Harold Ramis' direction is a true tour de force, ripping forward to the uncertain (if any) future of the hero. And when Murray jumps of a chapel (campanario/champagnerie), those of us who have not yet suffered a stroke from intensive spasms of laughter, enter a state of shock, a catharsis both on and off the screen.
Arguably one of the greatest comedies of all time, this Kafkaesque interpretation of one man and his weather demands repetitive viewing, until the onset of coma. View and be blessed...

Bill Murray says it all! He is one of my favorite actors of all time and never disappoints me. The repetition and the comedic timing make this movie one I watch every February 2nd. Also, beyond the humor, is the message that to change your life, you have to live each day as if it were your last. Everyone should at least watch it once, because it is a very unique movie.

If I was on some committee, with some award to give, for one of the most enjoyable movies of all time...Groundhog day would take the cake. It is a movie that somehow made me laugh and cry within seconds, and it made want to change things about myself that I never even knew existed until I looked at the life Phil Connors lead. This is a movie I would show to people I love, hoping to share all I feel about it with them. Bill Murray is a genius...as is Harold Ramis. How could this great movie be so underappreciated? The entire concept of this movie is one of the most unique I have ever encountered. But I guess that is how it goes...I for one, am glad I didn't miss it.

This is one of the best comedies ever made. Bill Murray does a great performance in this one, as the weatherman on a local news station. He travels to Puxatawney in Pennsylvania to bring the news of the Groundhog day. And he hates to do it. And he is glad when he is on his way home at the end of this day, but when they are on the highway, they have to go back because there will be a storm. Phil (Bill Murray) goes back to his bed and breakfast, and the wakes up the next morning with the same song in the radio as the day before. First he thinks it's deja vu, but after waking up again, on Groundhog day, he knows that there is something very very very wrong. He's having his worst day over, and over, and over again. And all the other people don't know, they just living the day. And Phil falls in love with Rita (Andie MacDowell), and he has to win her love everyday over and over again. This is a great comedy, just hilarious scenes, a great Bill Murray and some romance, over, and over, and over again.
Perfect, Bill Murray is the perfect guy for this role.

Review title: One of the best same day repeting movie
Review_body: It's not explaining the physics of the situation but it's good anyway. It shows the every site of the monotony and solutions of it. Hobo man's story left me in tears.

This was my first time seeing this movie and I enjoyed it just as much as I imagine most people did. It was an idea that has been done many times. This movie is one of the original movies with this idea and I think it was executed as well as it could have been. I liked seeing how his outlook on life changed every time he had to repeat the same day over and over again. It was obvious the first couple of days were going to be him trying to figure out what was happening. my favorite parts in this movie were when he had finally realized he could do anything he wanted with no consequences. He punched an annoying friend in the face, he said anything he wanted and he even killed himself....many times. Even though he didn't know exactly why this was happening he used it to his advantage. he used it to pick up girls and every time he would mess up on a date he could easily start the whole date over again because he knew the day would start completely over and nothing he did stuck. He would learn new information about people to impress them and pretend he was someone he was not. He was definitely smart but he did these things because he was bored and wanted to see how much he could get away with. I also enjoyed how relatable it was. I imagine ay person would go through the exact process that Bill Murray went through in this movie. The end was obvious but I still enjoyed watching him grow as a person. He began to do good deeds which he never would have done in the beginning of the movie. He becomes a genuinely good person and that is how he gets out of repeating the exact same day over and over again. Groundhog Day was funny when it wanted to be but serious when it needed to be. It was overall a very well thought out movie and I enjoyed it very much.

This movie was really good in my opinion. Its hard to make a movie that repeats the same day funny and Bill Murray made it funny his performance was very good. My favorite part is the beginning when he realizes that he is repeating the days he does everything that people would think of doing such as getting chased by the cops or robbing a bank. Also in the movie you see Murray's attitude change as he relives the days and he starts to feel sympathy for himself and others. It also made like the movie a little more and I would watch this movie again.

Review_body: The power of this movie is that it goes on and on and on just as the story. As soon as the movie stops repeating itself, it becomes a boring Hollywood flick. Nevertheless the repeating is so funny the movie is well above average.

The basic idea of this film, reliving the same boring holiday over and over again, already had a lot of potential. But the actual presentation of it couldn't possibly be done better. And with that it is a fact that any other movies trying to work out this theme are bound to fail hopelessly, as all the genuinely funny stuff about it already has been done in this one. If you've seen Clean Slate with Dana Carvey, you know what I'm talking about.Bill Murray is hysterical, and it is too bad that he rarely appears in a bullseye hit like this one. The rest of the film: the supporting cast, the music, the styling, everything hits the nail right on the head. It is my favorite comedy and I can watch it as often as I want and still I won't get tired of it!

Review title: Unusual that I enjoyed a film involving the supernatural so much
Review_body: It's not common that a film involving the surreal or supernatural - especially time travel - is so successful.  I think the reason for this is that once you enter that realm, literally anything goes.  That concept may seem exciting at first, but in practice it can become so illogical and have so little basis in reality that ultimately we can't relate to it.  Consider how silly time travel can become.  For example, in "Back to the Future", looking at a photograph and seeing the people in it start to fade?? C'mon. Or dealing with "paradoxes" such as going back in time and killing your grandfather.  What now?Not trying to explain how time travel occurs, this movie skirts those issues by simply backing up and reliving a day (there is no chance to "travel back to the future" - you must "live through it".)  One of the reasons it is so successful is that while ultimately a happy movie, the truly horrible feelings that would inevitably arise in this situation are also explored. Finally living through his day to the next day is a metaphor in this case for the maturing of the main character.  He does not know what is happening to him, but in the end he has been allowed a period of experimentation and growth.  Haven't we all fantasised about that?  For example, having 10 fresh chances to approach a person of the opposite sex we want to meet and seeing which works best?  In the meantime the film explores this journey with both humour and sorrow.  Having 10 fresh chances to try something sounds great if it's your *choice* - but not so great if you never get to stop the carousel and say "That's a keeper - let's get on with my life now!"  Few actors other than Murray could play this role so well - he seems perfectly cast. Enjoy!

I'm fairly certain that I have seen this movie at least 50 times and enjoy it very much. I have watched it 100% straight and 100% stoned on very good weed, my preference is to watch it quite stoned on primo bud. I have finally watched it so much that now I'm looking for real scientific miscalculations and the best that I can ascertain
is that there is one major inconsistency that just never gets thought about. Here it is: Phil is 100% aware that he is caught in a time-warp, reliving the same day continuously day after day. The inconsistency is that so does the rest of the town, except they are totally unaware that they too are living the same day over and over. Only Phil is aware that he has an ability to constantly change and improve. Everyone else experiences change,
but they are blissfully unaware that they too are reliving "Groundhog Day" over and over as well.Plus, there is the inconsistency of Phil predicting events that stay the same day after day, yet other events change day after day. I've always watched this without questioning that genuine scientific impossibility, even though I very much believe in the possibility that someday mankind might discover a secret wormhole that allows for time travel and existence in two places at the same time. The fact that astrophysics is coming around to believing the universe actually folds in upon itself, thus paving the way for wormholes to actually exist gives me far more comfort than believing in the concept of "God's" existence.

At first sight it looks like a ordinairy movie, but if you think about the two plots in the story of this movie evolving in eachother, consider that this movie is one piece of true art. Bill Muray in a both funny and dramatic position in this movie as the ordinairy weatherman who doesn't have the TIME to live. Faith shows him how time can spend in the best way and this is maybe something for the viewer to think about. A great movie in many ways.

One of the best comedies and one of the best movies ever made, and one which will grow in stature through time. A 'perfect film'. A 'perfect film' being not necessarily the most profound or greatest film, but one with no discernible flaws. Everything works, the writing, acting, how scenes are put together. Princess Bride is another example of a perfect movie.The plot makes this such an "odd" movie. It is its own category, its own genre. I go back to look at individual scenes for themselves. They are varied and wonderful. The absolute best of Bill Murray, and that is saying something. Andie MacDowell at her best too. But the more I see the work of Harold Ramis the more I admire it. He wrote and directed Groundhog Day. He and Dan Aykroyd wrote Ghostbusters. He wrote Animal House. The unique quality of Groundhog Day, the oddness of plot, comes from the creativity of Harold Ramis.

Review title: Can watch it over and over again
Review_body: Groundhog Day is definitely one of my favorite movies.It manages to combine comedy, romance, drama and originality in such an entertaining way that it can be watched over and over again and still be enjoyed.Of course the main reason why the film works is Bill Murray's wonderful performance as Phil Connors. I can't think of any other actor who could have done the role justice. Murray captures not only the humor, but also lets his character grow and become much more sympathetic as the film progresses.Harold Ramis, the director, also has to take great credit for this, as his pacing for the whole film is absolutely flawless. It's disappointing that Ramis has never come close to making this quality of film again...Also, Andie McDowell gives by far and away her best ever performance in this movie. Her and Murray have great chemistry and she is the perfect foil for him right throughout the film.This is truly and wonderful and uplifting film which everyone should see, and more than once!

Review title: A film that can change the way you see the life
Review_body: A minor thing for me is that the film is refinedly funny and that it develops at a continuous speed that you cannot be boring at any moment. An exception of that may be the first ten minutes, because the main character, Phil Connors, achieves to transmit his personal view of life, as a bitter routine. We, as he himself, don't have the minimum interest in the Groundhog day (sorry for those that love groundhogs). Since the moment that Phil Connors is trapped in time, the film is no more senseless. The thing that makes this film so valuable, and not recognized enough, is that it reflects our own lives. The first time that Phil re-lives the Groundhog day, one can think ¿what's happened? ¿which extrasensorial power has made him to be trapped in that date? Oh, well, it's just fantasy. But when you contemplate all the story, you realize that the reason is in Phil himself, the same as the reason why we live our lives as a boring routine is in ourselves. The first things that Phil Connors makes when he realizes that he cannot scape from that endless repetition, are funny, but nonsense. The happiness that we find in those things that we make to break the routine of our lives are funny too for a short time, but the entertainment ends very quickly, because our lives have no sense. The character of Phil Connors searches different ways of finding how to fill his eternal life, but the only one thing that can give sense to his life is LOVE. Not just the relation with that wonderful (until that moment undiscovered) woman, who is working with him, but love to mankind, to any person that needs us. Love means interest in their lives, in their worries. The way he finally breaks the spell can only be understood by those who have penetrate in the meaning of the film.

Most modern comedies either aren't really funny, are nothing but a funny movie, or three-quarters of the way through, they switch from comedy to solving a problem. Groundhog Day is funny from start to finish, even though we follow the main character through 34 Groundhog Days of personal discovery and growth. When I showed this movie to my then 10 year old daughter, Jessica, she was horrified by it for many years; she didn't see the comedy, she saw the hell of someone who has, as Sartre's play is named in English, "No Exit." Murray's character's inability to accept that he can not keep the old man alive when it's the old man's day to die is a movie moment that always brings tears to my eyes.This movie is one of my 50 favorites, and it's a hard list to make.

I checked the spoiler so as to not be accused of revealing anything that isn't already known. With that said, this film is a classic tale of redemption ala A Christmas Carol. Instead of ghosts showing him the errors of his ways and warning of the consequences, it is that he must live his in an unchanging way until it dawns on him that life is not what he made of it but what he should make of it. The most poignant part of the film is where he tries to save the life of the old man and realizes that there are things in life which are already determined and are immutable, but most of life is changeable. Listening to the soundtrack evokes powerful responses and imagery. I dare you to see this film and listen to the soundtrack and not be moved. This is what makes this film so great. Just like Scrooge, his transformation is complete and his life will be forever changed for the better.

It's a technique that you would use on an evil person. It will trap that person in an infinite time loop. The only way to break out of it is to have a change of heart, when you realize your mistakes, the bad deeds you did in your life deep from your heart. Basically once you become a good person, the loop will end.Continue reading if you are interested in Izanami....

It would cost them one of their superpower eyes. They will change the future come out as alive with one less eye.To stop people from using izanagi, someone invented izanami. It was superior technique. A user casts it on other person, en-trapping them in infinite time loop which cannot be broken until they realize their sins and have a change of heart. It will also cost the caster one of their superpower eyes.Izanagi was used to change one's fate and izanami was used to decide one's destiny.

Review title: Feel good, and a whole lot more
Review_body: I never thought there could be a "feelgood movie" to match 'It's A Wonderful Life'. Till now.What's a 'feelgood movie'? A movie that, quite simply, makes you feel good. In that, feel ONLY good. Not a single bad moment. That's a high peak to ascend. 'It's A Wonderful Life' ascends it. As does 'Groundhog Day'. Or at least it comes tantalizingly close.Like 'It's A Wonderful Life', this, too, is a fantasy film. And like 'It's A Wonderful Life', this film, too, is about goodness. Only, Jimmy Stewart, every so subtly playing George Bailey in the former, had to be SHOWN how good he WAS. Whereas Bill Murray, with a matchingly evocative depiction of Phil Connors in this, learns how good he can BECOME. 'Groundhog Day' is a purely, unabashedly spiritual film. Its premise is one that could easily have fallen flat, or become a basis for pulp kiddie fantasy fare - of an ordinary man getting stuck in a time loop where he wakes up, each day, to find it's the 2nd of February, all over again. Don't be fooled however ... that is merely the backdrop for an intensely, almost Biblically spiritual tale, of a man's transcendence - "transformation" would be too weak a word - from an intensely self-centred, unlikeable "jerk" (as he calls himself at one point), to a being of pure beauty, and goodness unalloyed. It displays how, placed in such an unenviable position, Phil traverses a gamut of emotions - from initial shock and fear, to the purely selfish realization that he can do whatever he wants without caring for the consequences, to ... well, I don't want to reveal too much - let's just say that, at first, he plays the day, and, later, the day plays him.It's a spectacular, and fittingly understated, performance by Bill. It has often been opined that no other actor could have done the role, and, watching Bill, one does feel so. Andie Macdowell is, however, equally luminous, and provides the halo to Phil's God (as he, again at one point, calls himself). They complement each other perfectly, and, together, tell us a tale which can never be forgotten.'Groundhog Day' is a cleansing, purifying experience. To call it a fantasy film - as Wikipedia does - is unfair, for it is SOOO much more. Why I am giving it 9, instead of 10, out of 10. I don't know. But I am. Let's leave it at that.

It is a wonderful event that such a filmin is happening on days when everyday life passes the same way.Blade runner and seven samurai. It's amazing to not get a prize. It's a great movie that reflects the importance of living alone.If you are bored too much, it will be a great movie to change your gaze, even if your annoyance will go away in a big way.

Groundhog Day stars many great actors, the most notable of them being Bill Murray. Playing Phil, a sarcastic and selfish weatherman, Murray brings multiple elements of humor to the movie. Phil finds himself stuck in the same day, Groundhog Day, and he has to relive it until he 'gets it right'. The setting is in Punxsutawney, a small town in Pennsylvania. The movie itself is a clever rom-com with a moral, and I applaud Harold Ramis along with the writers. The dialogue was hilarious, and the story was able to keep its more meaningful elements while still being funny. I'd love to watch it again, and I think it's better then most modern romantic comedies. 8/10

Groundhog Day is one of the most cleverly written/directed/acted movies ever produced. If you've never seen it, watch it without distraction. Undoubtedly, you will then be able to grasp the beauty that lies within (after repeated viewings, of course-not because they are required, but because you will want to). This movie is so well-made on many levels. If you're feeling down, this movie will cheer you up and probably change your outlook on life. I have seen this movie many times and I know it will be seen many more. It is that special. I am obsessed, as I'm sure there are many more that feel the way I do. Maybe you will be to. I tell everybody I know about this movie, and every one of them praised me for it. I've read all the reviews, plus I frequently read the IMDb message board for this movie. It kind of reassures me, I'm not the only one who "gets" it. Pass it along! Plus, this is definitely worth mentioning-if they were ever allowed to give retro Academy Awards, Bill Murray, as well as the movie itself, would easily walk away with the honor. The Academy people didn't really "get it" back then.

Review title: I've seen this movie so many times, it'd make you sick.
Review_body: Anytime I catch this movie being played on TV, I will drop whatever I am doing (short of, hmm, lets say open heart surgery) to watch it. I know most the lines by heart, and I don't hesitate to repeat them (al la Rocky Horror Picture Show). I think this is one of the best movies ever, and I should know, I've seen it probably over a hundred times.

Beneath the light and generally upbeat tone of this film lies one interpretation of "the meaning of life." Whether you espouse reincarnation or not, the idea of "doing it over until you do it right" is something one learns as one ages.Why is it some experiences happen once and others seem to recur in an unending pattern? No matter how hard you try, you find yourself faced with the same dilemma - in spite of a change of location, employment, even significant other.Groundhog Day offers an answer in an easy-to-swallow form. Take it on the level you choose, but if you plumb the depths on this one, you will find it very worthwhile.My hat is particularly off to Bill Murray, who appears aware of the complex task before him, and to the primary writer of the screenplay, who I assume is Danny Rubin. Unfortunately, Rubin  seems not to have followed up this effort with anything of comparable significance - yet.

Review title: An inspirational and witty comic fantasy
Review_body: This film is amazing.  Not only has Harold Ramis used wit and intelligence in a hilarious comedy as he did in Ghostbusters, but he has delivered a feel-good masterpiece that makes one think twice about the direction of their lives.  This film had much more than a story to tell, (although it's appearance of The Twilight Zone gone comedy is breathtaking) but it actually enlightens the audience to a whole new world of possibilities within their lives. Bill Murray is at his best as a cruel and cynnical but witty Pittsburg weatherman named Phil Connors.  After going to the small but lively town of Punxatawney to report the groundhog festival, he learns that he is doomed to repeat the same day over and over again.... until he gets it right. The antics Phil goes about are wonderfully imaginative, sparking the question in everyone's mind: What would you do if there were no tomorrow? When the film gets a bit more serious, Phil decides to impress the woman he secretly loves (Andie McDowell).  Unfortunately, every day she wakes up without any memory of yesterday.  Phil is the only one who this happens to.The interesting aspect of this film, as stated in a prior review, is the unmentioned amount of days Phil repeats.  After close analysis I found it to be about twenty years.  His learning different talents, such as piano and multiple languages, implies a span of many years.  Not to mention that a simple game he learned, throwing cards in a hat, took him months to learn. Imagine all the games he learned besides that.  "Is this what you do with eternity?" McDowell asks.

This movie is great.  I watch it every Groundhogs Day and even others and still love it.  I keep on laughing at all the humor even though I've heard them so much.  I think that it is amazing how well this movie works...no other movie have I watched as many times and still liked it. Okay maybe a movie when I was a youngster I watched billions of times but come on, I'm talking now. I recommend everyone to see it and enjoy it.  It is great to watch on February 2nd of every year.

If Groundhog Day for Phil Connors (Bill Murray) is the day he relives thousands upon thousands of times, then Groundhog Day for me is the movie I rewatch thousands upon thousands of times. You can watch this film many times before it is the case that you don't pick up on some new nuance of gesture from Murray or some other subtle perfection. One of my favourite lines: "You wanna know about the weather? You're asking the wrong Phil. I'll tell you about the weather. It's cold and it's grey and it's gonna last the rest of your life." His descent into despair allows for some of the best comedy of the film...Nowhere can a great comedian shine better than as a character who has hit rock bottom and has nothing left to lose

Hilarious!  A classic for the Bill Murray fan.  Andie MacDowell is subtly sexy as always.  What I appreciate most about this unique film is that it realistically addresses a question all of us have asked ourselves before..."What would I have done differently if I could do it again?"  (I wouldn't have raised my voice at my senior prom date--a stunningly attractive girl--because she didn't wait until I opened the car door for her.  We didn't know each other well to begin with and it ruined the evening.) We see through Murray the transformation of a man from self-centered to sharing, cold-hearted to caring, as he re-lives the same day over and over and over again.  My favorite scene involved a dinner date with Murray's film love interest, Andie MacDowell.  As they dine across from one another, discussing their interests, hopes and dreams, Andie highlights her love for European classics (or something similarly mundane).  Murray's character, in classic alpha-male form, bursts out laughing like "that's the dumbest thing I've ever heard in my life."  Andie is visibly hurt.  Cut to the next scene--same dinner, same conversation.  Andie--"I love European classics."  Murray - meditating on the profundity of Andie's statement, quotes a poem from that period...in French!  Andie--"I didn't know you had such an appreciation for those works."  Murray--"Oui"  (French for yes) Score 10 pts. for Murray in Andie's book.  For one day, we get to see someone live a regret-free, no holds barred, do want you want to, anything goes day.  Yesterday's mistake becomes today's victory!  I (obviously) haven't seen the film in awhile, but I recall little profanity and no nudity or violence, making it (somewhat) kid appropriate.  One of my favorite comedies of all time.

... very pleased! Everybody knows the premise. An egoistic, selfish and not quite likable weather man who has been covering the "GroundHog Day" celebration in a small town for the last 4 years, makes his views very clear on what he thinks to be stupid waste of time. He does not spend time with his crew members and after grumbling for some more hours goes to sleep. Next day, Mr. Fantasy kicks in his life, as he finds himself once again reliving "GroungHog Day"... And again... and again...Redundant to say, that in his ordeal of re-living the same day over and over again, he realizes his flaws and becomes a better person in the end... The storyline will have people screaming Frank Capra and Cary Grant(not James Stewart, he would be too "nice" for the main character). However, we get Harold Ramis and Bill Murray instead. And guess what? They make it a gem! Of course, major credit also goes to the script and editing department, which are razor sharp. And one can only visualize(if someone has not already seen the movie, and is a Bill Murray fan) as to what Bill Murray can do with an opportunity like this! The result is a hilarious comedy, along with it's touchy moments(not overdone, though there were plenty of opportunity for those) and the ultimate "redemption". The overall feeling - have to watch it again... and again... and again...

Not sure why everyone calls this a classic. There were a couple of laughs but for the most part, I was bored with it. The movie was about him reliving the same day over and over. Yet, I got upset because he was reliving the same day over and over. Scrooged is actually one of my favorite Bill Murray movies.

Review title: A deep and beautiful message in a funny and always appropriate movie.
Review_body: I would like to express myself on one of the greatest and maybe most underrated movies ever made. Contained within is a deep and beautiful message that everyone should take example from.Starting out as a sarcastic comedy, Bill Murray is Phil Connors, a self-absored and cynical weatherman. He's trying to climb the television network ladder, and though he might be on his way up, he still got a task to do that he hates above everything else. Every year, the famous Groundhog day in Punxsutawney takes place, and Phil has to make a cute report about this event. Of course, in Phils vocabulary "cute" is a synonym for "pathetic".He travels there with a news team, the cameraman Larry (Chris Elliott) and Rita (Andie Macdowell), the total opposite of Phil. She is a kind, warm and gentle person. Naturally, there is a big clash between Phil and her.They arrive at Punxsutawney, and Phil does a short and arrogant report and leaves shortly thereafter, to Ritas big annoyance. However, a snow storm forces Phil to stay one more night in his "favourite" town.Next morning he wakes up early, eager to leave this extremely cute and happy place. He looks out the window, and sees a very familiar sight. It's Groundhog Day! Out on the street, he becomes perplexed and yet convinced that this is the exactly same day as yesterday. Same things happen in same order. He manages to keep sane however, and falls asleep in the evening. Next day he wakes up to exactly the same song on the radio... Rise and shine, it's Groundhog day!I'm amazed how much truth and wisdom story writer Danny Rubin has put into this movie. First, Phil realize that he can do anything and no one can stop him. He tries out virtually every capital sin, only to realize that this is not it. After a while, he comes to the conclusion that the big change must happen within himself.It's this conclusion I feel is the most important, as it reflects the civilization and humanity every day. We can go cursing the situation around us, but that only ends up in torturing ourselves. We have to realize that one of the few things we really have control over is, that's right, ourself. And as shown in Phil's change after this realization, everything is within us. It's only a question of letting it out and stop the feelings that makes us feel bad.I'm not saying this is easy, it could be a lifelong process (or LOTS of Groundhog days), where you slowly have to realize that "this place might help me do something about myself". So was the story about Phil, anyway. Does he ever get out of his "personal hell"? Well, go rent the movie and find out!

Personally, this is one of the most deep and influential films I have had the pleasure of watching. If you dont come out after watching this film both, uplifted and inspired, then quite simply you have no soul.

Ever since I saw this wonderful movie, I became one of the Groundhog Day cultists. I send out Groundhog Day cards since 1993. It found Danny Rubin and thanked him for making such a wonderful movie. This movie woke me up and changed my life. What more can I say.... anything different is good!

Having just seen this movie again recently on TV, I forgot just how great it really is! I've always been a Bill Murray fan, but this surely must be his best performance ever. I won't say this is the greatest movie of all times since you will most likely disagree with me, but in my world it sure is.Back in good old Sweden this movie was very poorly marketed, but luckily some friends of mine discovered this movie a few years after its premiere and it quickly became our favorite movie. The basic genre of the movie is the "romantic comedy" genre, which is flooded by enjoyable but very average movies that makes time fly by without leaving any major impressions. I believe the genre also is the curse of Groundhog Day, people are supposed to leave their brains shut of when watching these kind of movies and no one is supposed to love romantic comedies, you are meant to like them. In my view Groundhog Day is the most underestimated work of art in the movie history....(or it might be that people simply have different tastes and just don't love the movie as I do, but when it comes to Groundhog Day I don't like that kind of thoughts ;) )The movie is about the art of enjoying your everyday life.... ....or it is a philosophical what-if-movie, about the eventuality of someone having to relive the same day over and over again, reflecting on the moral and psychological consequences... ...or it is a beautiful romantic film where someone manages to change into a better person in order to charm the woman of his dreams... ...or a hilarious comedy that makes you breathless while trying to stop laughing.If you don't like some of the different aspects of the film simply ignore them, you will still enjoy the movie.Groundhog Day is in my view the most obvious 10/10 movie. And I strongly recommend it to anyone, hopingly you will love it too and if you don't you will surely like it.

Time is nothing more than that: one day after one day after another. The only thing that tells us we are not living the >same< day once and again is the fact that we preserve our memories. To make use of time passing is one great advantage the human race has. This movie helps to understand this concept and the nature of time itself.A man who lives the same day, time and again, who has no consequences of his actions, who is trapped in time with no way out. He wishes he would be trapped in a different day, a day he would love to repeat once and again, but no, he is trapped in a common day, surrounded of people he barely cares about. He tries everything, even suicide. He also tries robbery, without fearing any consequences of his acts. He becomes extremely bored.He feels totally unhappy... until he accepts the situation and decides to try something different. He starts doing things he's not used to, he suddenly wants to learn to play the piano, avoid other people's accidents, gain the heart of a woman he first didn't care about at all, but whom he got to know until he finally fell in love with.It is this transformation and this love what pull him through time.The same day repeats over and over, until he lives a perfect day. And even though it is only a few hours he has until the end of the day, he actually got everybody to love him, the woman he loves gives him all her admiration and respect, he makes lots of friends and he uses the time in such a productive way that it is almost impossible to believe one person can achieve so much in "just one day"... He has become one superior man, he has transcended time.Only then he breaks the spell of time and time passes. He is no longer trapped in time, but he has learned to live now, from being an asshole he is now a great human being.But is this not the actual nature of time as we know it? Is it not actually the same thing as in the movie? It is up to each individual what he/she decides to do with his/her time on Earth, but life could actually be something beautiful, regardless of any personal circumstances.

This movie makes me think of when I was a child. I've always loved "time travel related" movies, like Back To The Future, Terminator, and so many others. This one does not have time travel itself, but it is related due to the fact that the day is repeating over and over again. The movie makes us think of attitude and what is really worth living for. It is a beautiful story, simple and joyful.

Review title: It's just what life is all about.
Review_body: My brother told me that some people say "ground hog" day is one of the most spiritual movies ever made. First times I watched the movie ( I already have seen it a dozen times) I just laughed about it. But after some times watching I saw what the director wanted to say with it.In my own life the same thing happened but not as heavy as in the movie. I mean, in my life the day just become another day. ( really I ask myself, the only thing that was different that was the date) I think a lot of people live in groundhog day, doing the same thing again and again, not taking the best out of life. Just living without any consciousness. Review title: Philosophy held in such a terrific movies
Review_body: Groundhog Day is a light comedy. But it is not just a simple comedy. It is somehow like the movie "Edge of Tomorrow " that the leading character experience the same day again and again. But the differences between these two fantasy movies is that in Groundhog Day, the only way to get out of the infinite cycle is to change person's attitude towards life, which makes this movie not a simple comedy, but a terrific movie with full philosophy on life.Often we hear the adage, "It is just a film". Well, but what if we truly face the similar predicament?Assuming that we all have to suffer the same day like Phil and whatever we did today would leave no impact on others tomorrow and what makes you awake everyday is a song saying I got you Babe , maybe most of us would react to this crazy predicament passively and madly like what Phil did at first, giving everything up as despair. But when we reflect the situation more calmly,we might live a totally different lives. Just as the Phil did in the movie,he took up piano, began reading, learned to ice-sculpt.Everything seems better than beforeThere are many truth conveyed in this movie, and I do appreciate such a ingenious movie. It reminds me how happy we are as we have such a bright future, in which we can achieve any marvel as long as we make efforts to it.

Review title: Why so late I found you,such a good movie!
Review_body: None of other films have touched me like this,by its comedy,as well as its philosophy at the same time.It is not just a film that only left you nothing but some echo laughters.Watching it,you can find many things that call for much deep consideration.What is the sense or aim of life?What will you do if everything you do today is "formated" tomorrow?Of course,everything!You can do everything,without caring about the results!Thus,it is not a bad thing that tomorrow is automatically like today.Try this,try that,and experience every thing you haven't dare to do,such as death.However,all the time,the terrible "loop" can not be bounced out of.One day when you have tried any possibility to satisfy yourself,what will you do next?Just like in real life,the progress of finding the answer is somewhat painful.Black humor usually brings laughters mixed with unexpected shock,pain,or even tears.But this film didn't do so.It was not pointed to the "evil of human being's nature"or something like that.Finally,it was love that helped and saved the protagonist.More exactly,it was the progress he found,pursuit,and give love.Is it a bit conventional?In fact,the way of getting real love is not as smooth as imagined.The more considerate the man made the dating,the more the women believed it was a track.After all,it's not an easy thing to make a women fall in love completely with a man who used to be arrogant,dismal,and self-central.Fortunately,the man could take the advantages of repetitious Groudhog Day to make himself more perfect.Meanwhile he found the neglected beauty and passion in life,begun to learn how to satisfy others instead of himself,and changed totally into a another person,though the circumstance was all the same in the morning.When the women really fell for the really cute man,he went through the Groundhog Day eventually.It is a film with multiple elements,such as romanticism,comedy,imagination,or philosophy.The story was described so well and the pace of the film was controlled so appropriately,that I even can't believe that it was shot so early.

Every once in a while it occurs to me that my time on Earth is finite. It's the thought that keeps me, and all of us, up at night. The planet is spinning on its axis, revolving around the sun – its motion terrifying in its ceaseless consistency.Bill Murray's work in the movie Groundhog Day is underrated: he walks a razor line between comedy and horror, waking up to the exact same day each and every day. Strangely, the premise of this film – that a man must re-live the same day again and again for eternity isn't a story about immortality. Ultimately, it's a parable about aging – a "cautionary tale" urging the viewer not to let his life fall into a numbing sameness of days. Instead, change things up. Take risks. Have fun. Do the thing you're afraid you might not be able to do. Even if you fail at it, you'll be able to say you gave it a shot. At least you'll have done battle with the sameness of your days. It won't slow down time, or stop the Earth's rotation and revolution, but you'll feel less like a hamster (or a groundhog) on a wheel.

This is one of the best stories in the movie that I've seen. Plunging into the desperation of the main character, you start to think about your days. And the conclusions that the character makes are applicable to real life. So that each day does not look like one - on another, just be a good guy and improve the world around you.

Review title: A fantastic concept, brilliantly cast and wonderfully directed.
Review_body: A film that was perhaps underrated by critics upon its release, Groundhog Day is a classic example of a film that has spread through word of mouth. Bill Murray is perfectly cast as the grumpy weatherman whose egotistical character would rather be in the studio than out on location. Andie MacDowell is equally great as the kind and caring 'environmentally friendly' love interest that contrasts diligently with Murrays bullish persona. The concept is something that almost every person has toyed with at one point or another - what would happen if tomorrow I woke up and re-lived today. With this in mind Groundhog Day manages to investigate this notion with humour, wit and a sense of class that makes it stand out as a great movie that will, I'm sure, endure the very thing it explores - time.

Review title: A rare example of a clever idea made into a great movie.
Review_body: A guy lives the same day over and over again. Sounds repetitive, yeah? Not so, this movie explores the concept so wittily that it keeps you interested right to the end. The director makes no attempt to explain WHY this person is stuck on the same day, and so avoids such cliches as Guardian Angels, Magic, Science Gone Mad, etc. Excellent!
Successfully capturing the magic of the old Capra films, Groundhog Day is consistently clever, moving and above all, very funny. Films such as this one are all too rare in this day and age.

This surpasses all the expectations one would have for the kind of movie that it appears to be: a whimsical comedy based on a 'what if?' premise, in which some fundamental assumption about the universe around us is altered, to amusing effect.  Films in this particular sub-genre (does it have a name? I think of these as 'Twilight Zone' comedies) have a certain appeal for me, but most supply a few laughs, not much more.  I usually come away from them with a sense of an opportunity missed, due to sloppy execution or lack of imagination.  The screenplay of "Groundhog Day" is outstanding, in that its creators evidently gave much thought to answering the question: if a person found himself inescapably, eternally repeating the same day in his life, just what _would_ he do?  The execution of this 'thought experiment' is so thorough that it passes beyond hilarity, beyond cleverness -- though the film has both qualities in abundance -- to reach a level of psychological, even spiritual profundity that puts Groundhog Day in league with the very best examples of its type, "It's a Wonderful Life" and "A Christmas Carol". All this from a Bill Murray comedy -- who would have thought! ("Scrooged", Bill's own version of the "Christmas Carol" story, wilts in comparison.) Anyone who liked "The Truman Show" ought to love this.  It crackles, it surprises, and it even moves, with Murray's dry wit steering us clear of sentimentality.  Watch and enjoy it again and again.

If a work of art is something which can express most complex ideas in a seemingly simple way, then this movie definitely is a great manifestation of artistic genius. You can watch this movie as a good-humoured comedy turning around the crazy idea of the same day repeating over and over and have all the fun you can ask for. The cast is great, with Bill Murray going through all the highs and lows coming with his situation, Andie McDowell at her loveliest and Chris Elliott delivering great one-liners. When you start thinking it over, it occurs to you that the script touches on the last questions of human existence. It's not easy to postpone the question about life's sense, when there is no more tomorrow to postpone it until. Watching the flick, you might not immediately notice the plot's depth, just as it takes Bill Murray's character some time to realize the time-loop he's caught in. But once it gets to you, it won't let go of you.

I'm not sure if anyone else has noticed this, but the movie seems to follow the Buddhist path to enlightenment almost exactly. For anyone who doesn't know, the path is similar to the steps that people go through when dealing with failure or death. First there is confusion, then denial, then anger, then reasoning, and then acceptance. In Buddhism, one has to first realize that there is suffering. Phil does not realize what is happening at first; it's a shock that the day is repeating. He goes to sleep the first few times, hoping the day will change. When it doesn't, he gets angry and begins to kill himself in numerous ways. In Buddhism, this would be akin to living life frivolously. Once Phil realizes this will not end the day, he begins to do good things. This is the bargaining stage. However, this is not true altruism in that he is only doing good in order to escape the day. It is not until he accepts his fate that he begins to do good simply for the sake of doing good, and not for selfish reasons. This is the first real step in attaining enlightenment: accepting that life is suffering, and choosing to ease the suffering of others. Through this idea, Phil is finally able to escape the day, which would be akin to escaping the cycle of reincarnation and attaining nirvana. Essentially, Phil is going through this cycle on a microscopic basis, one day at a time instead of one life at a time. Sorry for the long explanation, I just thought it was fascinating that such a funny and entertaining movie could have such a deep undercurrent, whether the producers meant it or not.

Review title: Want the scoop? I've got you babe!
Review_body: I watch Groundhog Day on February 2nd every year and it never gets old. This movie is my FAVORITE movie of ALL time. You may wonder, how can Groundhog Day be my favorite movie of all time? Well lead actor has to play a role, right? Bill Murray is a comedic genius. He so perfectly blends seriousness with being funny. I don't know that anyone else could have done that role any better than Bill. Bill had perfect chemistry with co-lead Andie MacDowell, and to the point where it was believable. Sometimes you see couples in movies and you wonder how they would ever mesh...well these two make it work perfectly.However, the acting itself isn't what makes a movie great, it has to be the script, right? Well the writing is great too. However, the sign of a true story is if transcends momentary enjoyment to more of an everlasting philosophical and/or spiritual benefit. I always ask people when they are about to watch the movie that if you had eternity, what would you do with it? Seriously, ponder on this a bit. What would you do? Essentially, this movie attempts to dabble in the philosophical and spiritual. The scene with the guys at the bar summarizes what comes next. Phil, played by Bill, looks hopeless in his scenario after he realizes he is trapped not only in Punxsutawney, but in Groundhog Day itself. Phil is talking to his bar mate, Gus, when Phil is asked posed with determining what kind of a guy he is while peering into his beer mug. You see, some guys would look at that glass and thing it was half full, but Phil looks at it and sees it as half empty.At this point, Phil had to consider what to do with himself going forward so he isn't wasting his opportunity. This then sets off the tone for the rest of the act: Phil does what I think most of us would do at first if we were posed with no consequences: indulge. He goes after food, sex, and money. He then sets his sights on Rita, played by Andie, to realize that time after time, Phil as his shallow self-reveals itself every time, does not have what it takes to get Rita to fall in love with him. He then becomes clinically depressed and tries to kill himself in every way he can imagine to no long-lasting avail. Phil just won't die.Eureka! Then comes the pivot. Phil seeks Rita's help for real by taking her to breakfast and saying "I'm a god" and then "I'm an immortal" and then "I know everything". Phil tries to prove his false assumption by telling all the fellow people in the diner's bios. Andie says that this is not possible and asks what he knows about her. Phil then tells a lot of romantic and intimate things about her that proves that he really can change and truly does love Rita. I feel that the next scene where he is sitting in bed with Rita during her objective witness of Phil's unnatural knowledge tells the story of how long Phil wrestled with his imprisonment in the day and town he hates. When tossing cards and hitting every time while Rita misses every time, Rita says it'd take a year to get good at it. Phil says "six months, four-five hours a day." Rita asks "Is this what you do with eternity?Pause! Is this what you'd do with eternity? I doubt it. Surely you could do good stuff with your time, right? I believe it is at this moment that Phil sets off to change his fate. The very next day he starts doing good things: feeding the homeless, rescuing kids falling out of trees, fixing flat tires, stop someone from choking, etc. It wasn't until Phil changed that he could change his fate, while scoring Rita's love along the way. Rita never could love a shellfish person, she was too good of a person. Phil fundamentally changed what motivated him, and thus became a good person. That is what Rita really wanted all along, and not someone who could pretend to care about her. What a romantic story! What a funny way to show it! What a philosophical and spiritual story! This movie has it all where it counts! Watch it with me on the next Groundhog Day, won't you? And don't forget to consider that even though you and I aren't trapped in Groundhog Day like Phil, we are certainly "trapped" in our own lives, and it us up to us to make the most good out of it.

I don't think the movie is that good. If they wanted to make a decent movie they should've made him live different things every day. The movie as it is just an example of lazy writing aka my own life.

Groundhog Day is the other feature-length film of the Twilight Zone and like the Twilight Zone, it's neither good nor bad it just is. Like the Twilight Zone, the time loop is never explained on why it started, why the main heroine falling in love genuinely was important or him falling in love with the town as well. It's like a slow burn where Phil loses his mind. We start off by getting to know him and understanding his personality. He's arrogant and narcissistic, pretty much an unlikeable guy that hates the setting of the movie. Then we get to the loop of the film when Phil realizes that he is constantly repeating the day and feels hopeless. Then he has this epiphany that he can do whatever he wants. He is later seen taking advantage of the time loop and using it to satisfy his desires. He binge eats, smokes, steals money, and sleeps around (Groundhog Day, 34:00-40:00). He's living a carefree life and doing as he pleases. This scene is where the Twilight Zone episode starts. As we watch him do all of the things that frankly anyone one would do if given the opportunity we start to see that doing whatever he wants is getting boring and really wants to get out. Then as the movie progresses we start to see not only personality-wise but physically how this is taking a toll on him. When he starts helping people out there is this scary wisdom behind his eyes. The man literally remembers killing himself with a groundhog he saw his own death. Yeah, he gives the homeless man money, gets coffee to his coworkers, learns how to play the piano, and ice sculpts. He even dedicates his time to save the old homeless man. He then spends the next loop saving and helping everyone. Then he is thanked by everyone at the party (Groundhog Day, 1:10:25- 1:29:00). Through this montage of him helping people and him growing as a person, we should also remember that he was basically broken down mentally to get to this place of kindness and wisdom by this supernatural force that has no origin. With all of that being said I love this movie. It's promoted as being a Romantic Comedy but when looking at it from a modern perspective it's actually a psychological supernatural comedy film with a dash of dark humor. It's really fascinating how time and shifts the tone and mood of a film. I recommend people watching this movie only to see how messed up in a classic Twilight Zone way it is.

Review_body: Groundhog day should've stayed in the 90s. I'm watching it for the first time in 2021 and I can say that the only way this movie would be good is if I was watching it for nostalgic reasons. Just like Shrek.

If I were to classify this film, I think I'd call it "Romantic Comedy/Fantasy". But that hardly does it justice. Bill Murray, as the obnoxious Pittsburgh weatherman Phil Connors, is hilarious, as usual. He was the perfect choice to play the self-centered Phil. To sum up the plot, if you haven't seen it: Phil travels to Punxsutawney, PA with producer Rita (Andie McDowell) & cameraman Larry (Chris Elliot) to cover the Annual Groundhog Day Celebration. (A real-life event, by the way.) After covering the celebration, they're stranded there by a blizzard. Phil awakens the next morning, or so he thinks, and soon learns a terrible truth: He's entered some kind of time loop & must live the same day over & over, again & again & again... Phil realizes that he can work this to his advantage. At first, he uses it as an excuse to abandon self-control & avoid responsibility. He takes up some unhealthy & risky habits, knowing that he can start over each day. He soon becomes despondent, however & tries to kill himself several times. Of course, he fails for obvious reasons. Eventually, he starts reaching out to help others in the community, which earns him their respect. In the process, he becomes a better person. But more to the point: Beneath the surface, Groundhog Day has a deeper meaning. The basic premise, in itself, raises the question: What power created the temporal loop in the first place? Was it God, karma or some unknown cosmic force? How long was Phil actually in the loop? Days? Years? Centuries? Would time have any meaning while he was in there? I think the movie purposely leaves these things to our imagination. Why has Phil been "sentenced" to relive this day indefinitely? Is it a divine judgment on his character? Is this his "Hell" or "Purgatory"? Is his karma catching up with him? Let's look at how Phil's life is changed by his experience: In the beginning, he's rude, obnoxious & self-centered. Being trapped in the time warp, at first, brings out his negative personality traits when he realizes that his behavior can have no apparent consequences. Some examples: He punches out a pushy insurance salesman. He steals money from an armored truck. He uses women, including Rita (on whom he has a serious crush). He smokes, drinks & overeats. He makes rude comments on-camera at the Groundhog Day Celebration. After several unsuccessful attempts at suicide, Phil begins to soften. He begins using the knowledge he's gained to reach out to others. He soon learns how to be in the right place at the right time to help people in need. Some examples of this: He saves the Groundhog Festival emcee from choking. He catches a little boy who falls out of a tree. He changes a flat tire for some elderly ladies. He comes to the aid of a homeless man & prevents him from dying of a heart attack. He even learns to play the piano & takes up ice sculpting. Phil eventually wins Rita's heart. Then he's released from the temporal loop & time again progresses normally for him. We can see, from this, how Phil Connors learns from his mistakes, changes his attitude & his outlook on life, steps out of his self-centered little world & is finally able to show true love & compassion for others. There's a definite theme of redemption & salvation here, which should appeal to Christians. Because Phil is given countless chances to change his ways, this could symbolize God's infinite mercy. This would appeal to Jews, Christians & Muslims alike. Hindus & Buddhists would appreciate how Phil begins to build up good karma through selfless acts of kindness. Phil's eventually release from the time warp may symbolize a rebirth, reincarnation, an ascension to Heaven or some sort passage into the afterlife. In conclusion, Groundhog Day, besides being a great comedy, is rich in symbolism. We could all learn something from it. I highly recommend watching it. If you've already seen it, see it again (& again & again & ...). Yes, I know it was released in 1993, but it's timeless. (Pun intended.)

Now in 2001 I've just seen Groundhog day for the very first time, on DVD. What a refreshing film. I just watched the movie for the umpteenth time. It never fails to make me laugh, it never fails to move me as a story, it never fails to impress me as a movie.I haven't read all 397 comments (I do have a life), but in the first couple of pages I noticed nobody spoke of the 7 stages of grief/dying. The screenplay uses this as a plot device. The next time you watch the film (I know you will), check out Murray's character as he goes through 1)Shock/disbelief, 2)Denial, 3)Bargaining, 4)Guilt, 5)Anger, 6)Depression and, finally, 7)Acceptance. Only when he reaches acceptance and becomes the beloved Phil known to the whole town, who loves Rita unconditionally with neither an agenda nor a timetable, do the fates release him to live in the present.The screenplay is positively rife with beautifully understated lines that crack me up. Many commentors have included their favorites. Mine is the bowling alley scene in which the guy responds to Murray and says, "That about sums it up." There's a long list of continuity goofs, but there's never been a movie in which they are more inconsequential. It's the massive continuity that does work that's the story here.Easily on my personal Top Ten list.

Apparently Bill Murray and Harold Ramis fell out over the direction of this film, ending perhaps the most commercially successful working relationship in the history of film comedy (Caddyshack, Stripes, Ghostbusters, etc.). It is hard to understand the dissatisfaction of either with the finished product. The movie is an absolute masterpiece. The writing is brilliant, original and fantastically layered. The story, which details the inner journey of a Pennsylvania weatherman who finds himself living the same day over and over again, is an allegorical representation of spiritual and moral growth that has resonated with people of all religious persuasions. But for those who like their films uncomplicated, unfreighted with symbolic meanings, the movie is enjoyable on any level. There is nothing pretentious about its ambitions. The acting is note-perfect throughout, and Murray's performance is revelatory. He moves effortlessly between slapstick physical comedy, romantic love, and suicidal depression; and any number of emotional states in between. I can't recall a bad performance by Murrray in any movie, but in Groundhog day he hits more high notes than he's ever hit, before or since. It's a shame the Academy has so little respect for comedy, because his performance in this film is better than many an Oscar winner. One of the best films of the 1990s.

While the experiences he has in these loops are hilarious, ultimately, its a movie of redemption that will make it one to endure for the ages. Written by Danny Rubin, the film has been prescribed by psychiatrists to their patients and has been the source of essays on the fundamental tenets of many major religions. I found an interview recently with Danny Rubin where he talks about how the film grew into the remarkably famous film it is today, and just had to re-watch it. Here's the interview if you're interested. http://bigthink.com/dannyrubin

Review title: How do you spend your eternity?
Review_body: A philosophical parable, a sarcastic metaphor, or just a sheer superb Hollywood-molded comedy, are the titles marked by different spectators. No body however can deny its greatness, although it did not win any award -even in the Oscar (may be nominated in that year as I remembered).Groundhog Day tells us quite an ordinary story: a cynical weather reporter has to repeat the same day Feb 2 in a little town he hates most, so he becomes a god, becomes immortal and wildered by this eternal and miserable day- and finally a traditional but never cheesy happy-end. What makes this movie far beyond a comedic clich¨¦? In my point of view, it is the outstanding theme that uplifts this movie. This hilarious movie has a serious and profound theme which bases on Dostoevsky's query If God had died, could we do anything as we like? or the equivalent, Pascals famous saying Without a God, humans degradation turns meaningless.Fantastically and dramatically, this poor reporter Phil Connors (Bill Murray) acquires a privilege (or a damn) to repeat the same day. That means everything he does in this day will have no consequences. When he wakes up in tomorrow morning, all the things happened in yesterday become a dream. Then he has to live through today repeatedly. Therefore, with this exciting privilege, Phil naturally begins to carry out all the actions he wants to do but dare not to do: to beat an annoying man, to gluttonize desserts without fearing heart diseases, to break laws and rile policemen, to steal money and luxuriously live for one day, to coax a lady into one night stand, to chase his female colleague Rita (Andie McDowell). However, before long, he gradually finds all these mischievous or wicked deeds to be insignificant and temporary, hence a mood of tiredness and despair fills Phils mind so that he decides to end his one-day-life. But, ending this nightmare seems not to be easier than behaving badly. He tries everything. He has been stabbed, shot, poisoned, frozen, hanged, electrocuted and burned. Nevertheless, the next day is still the same Groundhog Day.In this endless torment, Phil becomes to understand that under that circumstance, fame, vanity, lust, money, happiness, sorrow, even life all really turn ephemeral- lasting only one day long- except his mind and thought. To make his transient and eternal life more meaningful, Phil resorts to some grand things- doing good deeds to others. Henceforward, he begins to observe all the people in need, and help them out of trouble in the future. He catches a boy falling down off a tree in an exact time, helps two old ladies repair their car, saves an old man from being chocked¡­ He reads all kinds of books and learns to play piano in order to spend his eternity. Time goes on and on, everyday he repeats these routines cordially and tirelessly until the miracle happens- he finally makes Groundhog Day an end with embracing his love around arms. Phil Connors transcends, not only this torment, but also his past. That line he says is quite impressive: Today is tomorrow. Actually, almost every ordinary man has ever complained that he has to repeat routines and live through a watery everyday life, but not every one has ever tried to put his soul on it, and reap the fruit of the fair life. With the envy of Phils fabulous story, I cannot help asking myself: If I happen to have this trial, how will I spend my eternity? Moreover, this movie affirms an assertion of mine: A mediocre comedy makes you laugh and forget the sadness temporarily whereas an excellent one makes you laugh and confront the ruthless reality intrepidly.Feeling tired of my didactic analysis? Do not be scared. In fact, this Groundhog Day can be everything but a stern sermon. Except for the theme, the nearly perfect performance of actors (esp. Bill Murray), the elaborate and thought-provoking lines, the adept film editing of the director, all make this movie almost flawless. The shortcomings, if there are any, lie in¡­ well, I have tried to point out some, but I fail, because none of them is conspicuous and impeachable.In a word, never miss this Groundhog Day; it will not disappoint you.

Harold Ramis's film "Groundhog Day" revolves around bill Murrays character "Phil", a miserable weatherman forced to once again go on assignment to Pauxatuany to cover the annual Groundhog Day celebration. After forcing his way through the day his team encounters a blizzard on the way home which forces them to turn around. He awakes the next day to find that it is the day he just lived. Hilarity ensues and in the end he discovers he must find happiness and his true self before he is able to snap out of his funk. He falls in love with his coworker Rita played by Andie MacDowell and they live happily ever after. The theme of this film kind of reminds me of Jerry McGuire except it is actually funny.Before Phil can overcome his miserable existence and find true happiness he is forced to relive the same day over and over again until he gets it right. Faced with seeing Ned, the annoying insurance salesman, everyday this takes some time. Phil experiences all the ranges of emotions while working to the end product and the director does a great job of taking us through them. He tries everything to get the day to end before realizing that he needs to embrace the day and make the best of it.The author uses several good techniques to reinforce the theme throughout the movie. I feel that "I got you babe" music every morning he wakes up is a nice touch in reference to the happiness he finds at the end of the film with Rita. The lighting is also used to reinforce how gloomy and dull both the town of Pauxotowny is and also the existence that Phil is living. While this film is a comedy classic, it also shows a real lesson that people take for granted most of the time. We go to work every day and get into the same rut over and over without putting everything into perspective. This film shows that sometimes we need to take a step back and evaluate what is important to us and spend the time putting it into perspective.

Review title: A weatherman is sent to cover a story about a groundhog named Punxsutawney Phil.
Review_body: A weatherman is sent to cover a story about a groundhog named Punxsutawney Phil. He is not happy about covering the story because this is his third year. After doing the story and awaking the following day he discovers that "Groundhog Day" is happening all over again, and again, and again. He at first goes crazy about it and then he starts to realize that he can use this to his advantage. He then realizes that he will spend the rest of his life in the same place, with the same people doing the same thing. Phil Conners is the selfish weatherman for the local station WPBH-TV, Pittsburgh. He has no respect for hi co-workers as well as the viewers. He absolutely hates "Groundhog Day" which is held in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania. Phil is to cover this event with Rita and Larry who are the new producer and cameraman. After doing the broadcast Phil wants to leave Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania immediately. However, a snowstorm leaves them spending another night. When Phil wakes the next morning he believes he is experiencing déjà vu because he is reliving Groundhog Day all over again. He keeps reliving this day after day after day. He realizes that this may be his fate but also figures out that his actions have no consequences, but the knowledge can help him gain information about what he wants especially when it comes to Rita. Phil is given ample opportunity time after time to get the day "right". Just like in the movie "50 First Dates" where a veterinarian has to keep winning the heart of a girl he fell in love with because she has a short term memory. With every new day he has to start over and make sure he gets it right. In this movie the motif is relevant to this movie because it is where they keep repeating the same day. This is important because it helps the view to understand the theme of the movie. The lighting in this movie was high-key lighting which helped create an effective image for the viewers. All Phil Conners had to do was get the day "right". Until this happened he would keep reliving the same day. This helped him gain knowledge on some stuff he needed but it also helped him realize that he would spend the rest of his life with the same people doing the same thing every day. He was given plenty of days to get it right.

Review title: Wonderful, A Christmas Carol for all seasons
Review_body: I'm surprised this movie isn't more widely appreciated, it's at least as life affirming as the Shawshank Redemption which seems to be over appreciated (a nice film though). I think the title doesn't help, especially outside the USA. When I first heard of this movie I expected some gross-out comedy to be watched with a few beers on a Saturday night. What a wonderful surprise it was to see a movie I knew would always be one of my all-time favourites.This is a light-hearted movie on the surface with intellectual and emotional depth underneath. One of the best interpretations I've read compares Phil's predicament with Nietzsche's concept of eternal recurrence - try to imagine how you would live your life, every instant of it, if you knew all those instants would recur again and again for eternity, unchanged.This simple (but devastating) idea is explored in a delightful and enjoyable story that will surely be watched again and again in years to come.

I have a feeling I'm going to regret this...I work with a guy who insists that Groundhog Day is nothing more than a (bad) Saturday Night Live one-joke movie that goes on for two hours.I, on the other hand, view it not as a comedy, not as a romance, but as a deeply spiritual experience.Imagine if you will, a selfish, angry life and you die, and you're reincarnated not into a different life, but into the same life. I see each groundhog day as another incarnation - until Phil Connors re-evaluates his existence, not only in helping others, but also in self-improvement, (learn a language, an instrument.) It's only then, that after what could have been an eternity in his "own private hell" that Phil was able to move on to the next level of existence - in this case, February 3rd and a future with Andie.My closed minded coworker insists that I'm reading entirely too much into this movie. Perhaps I am but I like to think not.Peace, Jack
