Review title: Rare comedy movie with great philosophical undertone
Review_body: Just after watching Primer, quite a complex film on time loops (List of films featuring time loops), I decided to watch Groundhog Day, a romantic comedy.~~ Spoilers below ~~This movie also features time loop where the protagonist "Phil" gets stuck in a tight time loop where he wakes up, again and again on 2nd Feb, the Groundhog day. Whatever he does on that day, goes away the next morning where he starts afresh. Only he has the memory and awareness of this loop. For everything and everyone else, this is a fresh start. For example, if he breaks a clock, the next morning it will be renewed, same with breaking somebody else's nose. Only he would have the memory of breaking the stuff. When he realizes this, as expected, he tries to get the max out of this situation in a hedonistic way. As none of his actions would lead to any consequences, he can now do whatever he wants. He also uses his ability to have multiple passes to the same events, gather larger world knowledge and use it to his advantage (securing a date for example). While doing so, he realizes his actual love for Rita, his co-worker. But however he might want to impress her, things just does not work out. He then contemplates suicide. And does it. But however he tries, he wakes up just the same at 6 am on Groundhog day. There is just no tomorrow for him.Once he is completely bored with suicides, he tries to build up skills. He learns, ice sculptures, piano, car mechanic's job and many different things. With multiple repetitions, he also has much more knowledge about the stuffs that happen on the small town. He uses these two knowledge to help many people around him. And finally, with all these, he manages to win the heart of Rita. Once he does that, tomorrow comes back to his life. He wakes up on 3rd February.That being the story, there are many philosophical, spiritual and metaphorical undertones in this movie.First, the repeat of 2nd Feb in Phil's life, in some way is a metaphor to our own materialistic, repetitive, absurd and boring days. And unless we do something significant, like learning piano like a pro, or helping out someone from choking, or finally getting our dream date, there is just no tomorrow for us. What we see as tomorrow is just the repeat of yesterday. As it comes out from this conversation between Phil and Ralph whom he meets at the café. Phil: What would you do if you were stuck in one place and every day was exactly the same, and nothing that you did mattered? Ralph: That about sums it up for me.Each day, learn something new, feel something new, do something new. Make sure today you do something different from yesterday.It also touches life in another philosophical sense. Like Phil's 2nd Feb, our own life may very well be as pointless and may lack purpose, that does not mean we won't do our work or would not try to be a better person. Our life may be as pointless as the life of Sisyphus; but that does not mean we need to be unhappy about it. "This story of a man doomed to relive the same day over and over again is not concerned about tomorrow. A true absurdist triumph, it cares not what the destination might be, for it knows that the pursuit of meaning is itself meaningful whether or not that pursuit is eventually rewarded.[1]" Just like it is told in Karma yoga.It also has a spiritual and philosophical undertone. Each 2nd Feb in Phil's life seems to be corresponding to the life. And just like Phil, we are stuck in endless cycle of birth and death, bound to the wheel of time until we get the promotion to next level [2].Overall it's a great movie. A simple take on a complex subject such as time loop. Go watch it.References: [1] http://www.slantmagazine.com/house/article/imagining-sisyphus-happy- a-groundhog-day-retrospective [2] http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/great-movie-groundhog-day-1993

I love this movie for all the obvious comedic reasons, but what makes it special for me is how it perfectly captured 4 years of my life at my companies regional meetings. We literally discussed word for word the same issues and solutions for 4 straight years every three months. The only thing different was the backgrounds of the power-point presentations and the % differences in growth quarter after quarter. About 3 meetings into this trend, I dubbed our meetings groundhog day. Did they change? Sadly no, they just started saying, "we want to avoid another 'groundhog day' in every presentation. I hope you are able to avoid this tragedy at your company. Great movie, and hilarious business analogy.

Review title: a nice film to watch i guess
Review_body: When I read the plot of this movie, it really made me curious. How would it really be, if there was no tomorrow? How would I react, and what could I do to stop it? Well, Phil (the main character of the film) was prisoned at the groundhog day, and couldn't find a way to live the next day. That did lead him to something really inspiring and thoughtful. After many things he tried in order to make 2nd of February seem somehow different, he couldn't manage to change it.With a mix of romance, comedy and nice character features, this movie is a very relaxing one that I would surely recommend with some warm tea or chocolate.

I will not waste your time w/ boring details of funny and knee slapping events of Groundhog Day. The fact stands that Bill Murray is one of the greatest comedic geniuses of his time. I cannot explain the grace and charm Bill releases into the texture of the movie. It is hard to fathom another actor who audiences have the patience to sit through and watch a man, over and over again, fail miserably at winning the girl's heart. Phil's transformation from a demon to a saint is well accommodated by Bill Murray's physical versatility. He can portray a "glass half empty" character and still be left with grace, or he can bring out a believable kindhearted soul that audiences follow with admiration. It is my opinion that Harold Ramis did not directly create the character, but let Bill Murray manifesting himself into the character of Phil Conners. I know very little about Harold Ramis' creative techniques, but I do know that he is a great man for making the executive decision to place his old friend Bill Murray into this role. I am speaking out of my rear end and this is just my opinion, so if there is any discrepancies do not write a counter comment please. Bottom line: Led by Harold Ramis, Bill Murray needs to team up with Andie Mac Dowell once again and create "Another Groundhog Day".

Review title: More than a funny movie, a life lesson
Review_body: On this movie, Bill Murray ends up stuck in a rather boring day of his life. He's unhappy with his job and is covering by the third time in a row an event that has no meaning to him. At first he's skeptical and shocked with everything that's happening. He just wanted that day to end since the beginning. His plan was to get there on the night before, sleep, do his jog and go back to his city as soon as possible. But a snowstorm closes the road and his group is forced to spend one more night there and this night is the one that starts to repeat the day making Bill's character stuck. When he realizes what's happening and that there's nothing he can do about it he just stop caring. He drinks, smokes, mock the coverage and the city, steal and do everything he wouldn't do if he knew that the time would pass as normal. He tries to learn about things to use this knowledge in his favor. He ends up knowing everything about the city, the schedule, people's life and preferences. With that he's able to make the day go exactly as he wants to. Eventually he grow tired of it all and just want things to be normal again. Sure it was fun to lie and live the life as nothing bad could happen to him but he misses what we all got, the possibility of a future. And the great lesson we can get from the movie is to try. You don't need to live like this day is going to repeat forever but instead of wait and think about the consequences of your acts just do it. If you wanna do something, get out there and do it. If you don't do it you'll be like Bill's character but in a bad way. The days are going to pass but you'll be stuck always doing the same thing.

I don't know what it was about that movie that made it so memorable, but I think I have seen it 500 times. It is really one of those movies that will stay with you throughout the years. I think we have all wanted to be able to go back and re-do a day or two in our lives until we get it right. I love that there is a happy ending. Bill Murray is a comic genius in my mind and it always entertaining to watch. I think I was about 7 when this movie came out and I was one of those kids that would watch a movie on repeat for weeks on end and this was one of my favorites. I think this movie truly stands the test of time. I wish I could say the same for half the movies that have been released in the last five years. Sometimes the effects just mask a poorly written movie.

Groundhog Day is an outstanding comedy-fantasy film about an egotistical TV weatherman named Phil Connors, played by Bill Murray, who resents being forced by his Pittsburgh news producer to head to Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania and cover the reveal of whether the groundhog will see his shadow on Groundhog's Day. Thinking he's a god amongst women, he assumes his travel producer Rita, played by Andie MacDowell, lusts after him and he can't help but take pot shots at his cameraman Larry, played by Chris Elliott. Once Phil has completed his day and is trapped overnight in Punxsutawney due to a blizzard closing down the highway back to Pittsburgh, he ends up in a time loop that forces him to repeat the same day over and over. He seems to be the only person who remembers already going through that day previous and even when he gets so desperate as to kill himself, he continually wakes up at 6AM on Groundhog Day back in his bed and breakfast room.The movie focuses itself around the theme that to really achieve anything in life we must let go of ourselves and open up to those around us. Phil remains self-centered through much of the film. After he first tries repeated attempts to kill himself due to the imagined torture of spending eternity repeating a day he deems miserable, he continues to make the same mistakes as he takes advantage of the knowledge he gains to seduce Rita and steal money from an armored car.For much of the movie, the lighting is pretty drab. Groundhog Day in Punxsutawney, at least through Phil's eyes, is very dull. Setting the movie on Groundhog Day in Pennsylvania as opposed to Miami Beach on the Fourth of July was obviously not just a coin flip by the writers. We are supposed to see the same dull, blandness that Phil sees and this lighting in Pennsylvania in February is very believable. In fact, we barely get even a hint of sunlight until the very end when Groundhog Day finally ends and life for Phil continues, lesson learned.The camera angles in this movie really reveal a lot about Phil as well. Much of the time we are looking up at him even if just slightly. This gives the impression that he's bigger than he really is and points to his inflated ego. When the camera cuts back and forth between Phil and whoever he is talking to in over-the-shoulder shots, we are looking from Phil's view down toward the person he is speaking with and up toward Phil from the opposite angle. On characters like Rita, this could be passed off as being because she is much shorter than Phil. But this angle is even used on characters the same height as Phil, such as Ned Ryerson. The exception to this is the Sheriff that closes the highway in the blizzard. In this case, the camera angle looking up from Phil toward him indicates the Sheriff's power but we also notice that we don't see any of Phil in these shots. As Phil starts to change his ways toward the end of the movie, the camera no longer looks down on the others but even Rita, who is obviously shorter, is shot from a lower angle as well making all the characters appear to be on level playing field with Phil.The film has a similar theme as another Bill Murray movie, Scrooged, which of course was based on the Charles Dickens' story A Christmas Carol. In both films, Murray plays a self-absorbed man who learns he must change his ways, however, Groundhog Day does a much better job with its message. This movie you can easily see the true struggle Phil must go through to open himself up to those around him and think about everyone else instead of himself for a change.

First,I should say that I watched it just because of Bill Murray! And I love all thing what are in this movie. I love this movie,not only it is one of the best, most original, clever and funniest comedies I've seen, it also makes you think of the serious questions. For example,you realize that how many fail do you in a day. And you realize if you had a chance to live your day again,you would do everything more good. You are witness that Murray's character Phil learns and grows and becomes a better person. He is living same day repeatedly. And he became better,lovely person. Watch it,and you will think that; If you could live today again,what would you do,you live same or you change everything?

Harold Ramis's "Groundhog Day" (1993) is a romantic comedy that is filled with laughter, love, and at times a feeling of hopelessness, over and over again. "Groundhog Day" is a about a local, self-centered weatherman named Phil Connors (Bill Murray) who has been sent to cover the infamous February 2nd festivities, better known as Groundhog Day, in a small town named Punxsutawney, Pa. Teamed with his lovely, well- grounded producer named Rita (Andie MacDowell) and his young, wise cracking cameraman named Larry (Chris Elliot), the three make the annual pilgrimage from Pittsburg to Punxsutawney for this historic event.We all know the story behind the famous date of February 2nd. If the "weather predicting rat" (groundhog) as Phil calls it, comes out from its burrow and sees his shadow then it's another 6 weeks of winter. If no shadow appears, then happy days are here because spring is near. Although Phil has been to the small town of Punxsutawney five times to cover the festivities, he does not intend to spend any longer than necessary to uncover the story, announce the prediction and get back on the road to Pittsburg. Phil wraps up the story, Larry packs the van and the three get on the road to head home. Here lies the problem, a winter storm is brewing and moving in the direction of Punxsutawney. The crew did not make it far before the road was closed by the Highway Patrol and were directed to return to Punxsutawney much to Phil's dislike. This is where Phil's vicious loop of the dreaded February 2nd begins.The storyline of "Groundhog Day" closely reminds us of the film "Yes Man" (2008) starring Jim Carrey as Carl Allen. In this story, Carl has committed to saying "yes" to everything. Soon he understands the magical power of the word yes" and his life is turned upside, sideways, and all around. Soon, Carl discovers a new love in his life, Allison, played by Zooey Deschanel and attempts to convince her that his love for her is real and he is not just saying that under this magical spell. Groundhog Day allows Phil to relive February 2nd over and over again. This motif gives Phil the latitude to develop his character during the film. He learns to be a better person through caring for an elderly gentleman, taking piano lessons, and reading more books and poetry. His sense of maturity is soon recognized by his attractive producer and sparks an interest to him. During this film there was not much use of lighting and colors. This could have been partly because of the mood that Phil Connors was feeling in addition to the dreariness of the nearby winter storm. This lack of lighting gave the appearance the days were meek and mild with overcast.Many times the camera angle gave the impression that they were stationary utilizing an objective point of view just to observe the action. However, there were times during the film when the cameras would pan overhead to recognize a crowd gathering at Gobblers Knob or give a subjective point of view like when Phil steals Punxsutawney Phil and drives over the cliff at the rock quarry. When Phil appeared in his bed every morning, the film crew utilized a high camera to stare down at Phil as he was lying in his bed before his alarm clock would go off at 6:00 am.No matter how many times you see this film, it will leave a lasting impression. The term "groundhog day" has become part of the free dictionary meaning a situation that repeats itself. This film is entertaining providing good, clean, wholesome comedy with a romantic twist that appears to never end.

Review title: Happy Groundhog Day, Happy Groundhog Day, Happy Groundhog Day. Redundant? Life? Eventually the next day will come.
Review_body: One of the best movies ever made. Reminds you that we keep repeating our days without making change. Until we DECIDE to change. One day, the next day will come. Excellent Film. This film is a film that will resonate with anyone who has the patience to understand how much their own lives parallel the story line. We can't help but relate to the ups and downs and frustrations of being stuck. Yet, in the end if we could all see how by making a change to manifest the lives we desire by simply giving and appreciating things as they are and while making little (one step at a time) strides. Life blossoms and eventually the change is seen.

A fantastic idea for a movie and the part played by Bill could not have been better cast, his persona and facial expressions are just perfect.the only bad comment i have of this movie would be that the morals of the movie at the ending are so predictable and so Americanized, they should have just left him there day after day just going round in circles would have been awesome or for that fact multiple endings you choose the one you want. The supporting cast just superb with all members putting in excellent performances backing Bill up with just impeccable comedy timing, probably with some help from the director, maybe not. But all in all a very enjoyable light comedy could have been better with some darker humor..

Review title: The most wonderful comedy of the 90's
Review_body: Groundhog day released in 1993 is the best movie that I have ever seen. I have seen many movies. More than a thousand and it is much better than most of them. One of the better aspects of this movie is its humor. It is rich, intelligent and never vulgar. There are some romantic scenes, they are not my favorites but I have seen worst. I forgot to tell the movie genre it is a comedy mostly with romance and some philosophical themes. The main actor is Bill Murray who gives a stronger performance in his comedies (like Ghostbuster) than many other actors. I could even say than it is his best and more nuanced performance. I have never felt such different emotions than when watching this movie. It is much better than other comedies of the 90's. Watch it! It will make you cry, laugh and ultimately think.

Review title: Great movie! Well written and produced!
Review_body: The film Groundhog Day takes place in Pennsylvania and is based around an annual celebration of Groundhogs Day itself. Bill Murray plays a person named Phil Connors who seems to be an arrogant self-centered individual who does not want to utilize his profession to cover this event. He works alongside his news producer named Rita who is played by actress Andie MacDowell. Phil Connors also has a cameraman for the news station named Larry who is played by Chris Elliott. Phil Connors shows up at the Groundhog Day event to do the coverage of this event even though he is not wanting to. Phil Connors plays a meteorologist in this film and he does not predict the weather right on this day. A big snowstorm hits the small town in Pennsylvania where he is covering the Groundhog Day events. When this occurs Phil keeps reliving the same day over and over again.Phil tries numerous things to get out of the time loop and one of these things is committing suicide just about every day. Once he realizes he cannot get out he decides to take advantage of this situation in a negative manner. He begins breaking the law by driving intoxicated, stealing money from people and taking advantage of women. He then realizes he has feelings for his news producer Rita which then turns everything around. Phil then develops what I would say is a hero's complex and begins doing well. By the end of the film he is a changed man and has a different view on his life as well as life with others. The theme of the movie Groundhog Day in my opinion is that one person's unhappiness whether with life or their job can be changed only if they choose for things to change.Another film that comes to mind that has a similar theme would be the movie Click where Adam Sandler has a remote and he can fast forward, pause, stop, play and rewind his life to get things "right." This is similar to what Phil Connors was doing in the movie Groundhog Day. The lighting in this movie was amazing especially for the year it was produced and released. The lighting showed different aspects and placed emotion on different scenes throughout the movie. Overall, it was a great use of lighting. The angle the movie took as well was brilliant as this helped draw a crowd. The movie kept me on the edge of my seat wondering what Phil was going to do that same day he was reliving and such. No matter what we are faced with in life with our job or personal life if we need to get things in order and make a change we are the only ones responsible for doing so.

This is just the greatest movie ever made!!! I think that this movie is just perfect: You have everything in it from Romance to Comedy to sometimes really deep topics. I also like the soundtrack and one very special thing: although the movie was, as far as I now, a hit, they never did a sequel, which is absolutely right, because this movie is one of the rare ones, that are absolutely self-contained. Bill Murray is a great actor and gives his best. You see his perfect play very good in the scene when they build the snowman the second time - the constrained way he acts, when he falls down to the ground and tries to come closer to Rita as naturally as the day before. If you're able to speak or at least understand German, check out the dubbed version with the great Mr Elsholtz (who is also the voice of Tom Hanks and Kevin Kline)!

Review title: Every time is like the first time
Review_body:
It's been 6 or even 7 years since I watched this masterpiece. Possibly, you would argue: 'Hey, if it is a excellent movie, what is Titanic, The Godfather and The Shawshank Redemption?" Well, if you are still not bored after a hundred views, it is perfect movie for you. And it holds for me. Easy, but important idea is the key of everything. This is love we all want in our lives.
And I should note pretty good acting of Bill Murray.

I really like this movie.....I saw it years after it came out, and I admit "The Razor's Edge" (also a Bill Murray movie) is another of my favorites. However, I think that for some reason, the people that gravitate toward this film also tend to be "karma sympathizers", slightly Hindu, or at least appreciate the spiritual parallels.If someone as cynical as Bill (Phil) can be redeemed on the day where for thousands of years, a small little animal has to choose between the dark and the light, than anyone watching knows they too can go out and be a better person. I had forgotten it was Paxsutawney Phil's day to shine till I looked at the news today, but just remembering that film, and its story line makes me want to go out and do something nice for my kids today. Maybe we'll go get cocoa before dance lessons- the sun is shining here! Happy Candlemas/Groundhog day to all...MM

Groundhog Day is a movie about a creepy shtbag who relives the same day over and over and uses that inconvenience to gaslight and manipulate women into thinking that he's not a creepy shtbag. In some alternative universe (1993?) this is apparently supposed to be funny or romantic. Imagine how many women viewers have been fed this "your love can change the a**hole"-narrative over the decades. As per usual in this genre, all the women are also portrayed as sex-objects who are either airheads or without much of a personality. Not to mention the illogical time-concept where he bumps into the exact same people in the same place despite having skipped events, unlike the day before. The protagonist clearly isn't the sharpest knife in the box, considering that he never even made a serious effort to leave town and go to bed somewhere else to see if the time loop is bound to the hotel/town where he's visiting. Apart from the rampant sexism and lack of logic, you can also predict the ending about half way into the movie. This movie is hardly alone in pushing the very destructive "it's just part of the romance when a guy is being a dipsht to you"-agenda, and that is exactly what is so terrifying. The frequency with which this agenda is pushed in this genre is partly why so many people can watch a movie like this without recognizing the problem of that this sexist dramaturgy both mirrors and contributes to creating sexist values in our society. Pure Hollywood garbage that should never have made in to the big screen.

Review title: Life changing Movie. How to make a new breathe into your life
Review_body: It's an excellent movie! - 20 years passed and its still actual and interesting! And this tradition of groundhog day its still going on. - An interesting thing that groundhogs name is the same as the man's name in the main role, and they are both weather forecasters :) - The curious thing is that the main character passes through several stages from the first state when he hates his job, the people that surround him, environment, he hates his life. And people that surround him also feel it, they feel negative energy from him, his egocentric nature. And when every day your life repeats, when nothing changing around you, you lose your desire to live. And then the second state - the main hero tries to satisfy his own desires, having every time in the world. But this didn't work for him. Then the third state he begins to learn new skills, to get new knowledge. It helps, but not satisfy him, nothing changes. And finally he understands that most important thing is to help others, to save more lives, to make more people happier. And from selfish man, that he was at first, he becomes a generous, very kind, and altruistic person. And the moral of this movie is that our life, given to us by God, is not for only satisfying our material needs and selfish desires, but for helping others, saving lives, learning and developing ourselves, making this world better and people in it more happier.

Review title: Great family fun with a moral
Review_body: Bill Murray at his best wry, sarcastic and aloof. The joy and humor hold through many viewings. Andie McDowell is a great heroine pushing and making the story line come to life. My children have grown to love the movie as much as I do, and have laughed at different parts as they matured. There're so many nuances, and moments that get found and that are anticipated that you laugh the moment before it happens. I marvel at the timing and movement as you are drawn through the growth and changes faced by this unwilling human ( Phil Conners)as he faces life head on. There are many outstanding supporting performances by Chris Elliot, as the cameraman the dumb and dumber twins of Ralph and Gus (Rick Overton and Rich Ducommun). It's one of those movies that some hate but most love. Including my family.

This is one of my top 5 movies of all time. It is one of a very short list that I have seen over 10 times. I never get bored with it because the setting of the movie is so convincingly laid out that you feel like you are able to spy on the characters as the story unfolds. This is a rare quality that I have only seen with a few other movies: "Fargo", "Cape Fear" (the one with DeNiro), and "It's a Wonderful Life" It is similar to how you would feel if you were able to see a film of close friends in an entertaining story. You feel as you know the people and the place. Fantastic! Bill Murray is Outstanding!! Chris Elliot is a funny supporting character. Andie McDowell, however, leaves question as to Bill Murray's Characters taste in women (a little too angelic for my taste - doesn't fit at all with his character). The townspeople have a strong role in this picture. They are the Currier and Ives simple-folk backdrop to Bill Murray's city-slicker character.

Now this is another of the typical, all-American eat-the-psychology-raw style of movies. It starts quite engaging with the repetition of the same day, over and over.If you haven't seen it (and abstained from reading the other 5722 comments), there is a TV commentator who has to live through the same day over and over again.Mid-movie, it get's quite interesting: he get's suspicious about the others; plays tricks with them; plays God the all-knowing; plays guardian angel. Plays let's fall in love. That's where the kill-all of US movies comes into play: triple sugar coating. Love with another woman heals all. Just be nice & all. Violins start playing. Snow _is_ already there.Really--great beginning, but pretty wasted.

Inspires me a lot.. 
Sometimes we need to take break from life itself like giving a pause to life, I guess.
That's why death is there to keep life valuable.
also if we keep taking break, then there will be no fear of death.. :) I believe

Review title: Excellent film showing a variety of tones...
Review_body: Groundhog Day takes place in the town of Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania. Phil Conners is a weatherman that is sent to Punxsutawney to cover the Groundhog Day festivities for his local news station. Accompanying Phil are his producer Rita and his cameraman Larry. Phil finds the assignment in Punxsutawney to be beneath him and wants to get in and out as fast as possible, unfortunately, the weather does not cooperate and they find themselves stranded in Punxsutawney.Begrudgingly, Phil spends the night in Punxsutawney and when he wakes up, he finds himself reliving Groundhog Day. He is the only person that knows what is happening and he goes through several different stages. He tells Rita that he is a God, he gets depressed and tries to kill himself, and finally, he accepts his fate and starts to better him. He grows fond of the people of the small Pennsylvania town. He eventually learns to play the piano as well as create ice sculptures. Eventually, Phil becomes such a good person and Rita falls in love with him. That results in Phil waking up in his bed, and discovering that it is February 3rd. I feel the theme of this movie is that if we seek true happiness, we must first be happy with ourselves. By the end of the movie, Phil is no longer a grump and has genuinely changed for the better. He is happy.Bill Murray, who plays Phil, is an excellent choice for the lead because of his "everyman" appearance. He does an excellent job portraying Phil going through the stages on his way to acceptance and eventually happiness. The tone of the movie changes as Phil's feelings about his fate change. There is an ominous tone early in the film with the storm. That switches to a light hearted tone when Phil is having fun with his new found fate. He steals money from an armored car, seduces an attractive woman, and gorges on desserts with no fear of repercussions. As depression sets in, the tone of the film turns dark again. Phil tries to kill himself in a variety of ways. Finally, when Phil decides that real change and growth are needed, the movie reflects that with a jubilant tone.

Review title: The "tightest" movie I've seen, underrated too
Review_body: (It's a shame this film is not on the IMDB top 250, as it is better than most on that list. The Academy was AWOL as well, only the Brits were sharp enough to award it.)Granted the core story-idea of this film is not epic, and a bit silly on the surface. It's no "Gone with the Wind," as they say. Just a lighthearted, low-key popcorn movie. But given this, you get the best screenplay, character development, dialogue, acting, editing (etc) possibly built on such a foundation. And it's not just technical-poignancy and heart abound. Film students take note.So, why is it tight, an odd way to describe a movie, no? I'm reminded of this famous quote: "Perfection is achieved, not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away."-Antoine de Saint-Exupéry.There is essentially zero wasted time in this gem of a film, it's just under an hour and forty minutes of focused storytelling with perfect pacing. Every scene supports the narrative, every line is great to better. There's no special effects or other filler. There are however dozens hilarious moments that continue to be after repeated viewings. Contrast this with any favorite modern-day film that should have been an hour shorter.Performances/dialogue are fantastic. Another full review celebrates Murray's "understated a-hole" delivery, I'll simply concur. MacDowell is adorable, sweet, and borderline annoying at first, but definitely grows on you. Only Elliot's (the David Letterman cameraman) performance is a bit self-conscious, but he still nails the resentful-nerd angle.Even minor characters in the town get substantial development all things considered. We immediately grasp everyone's motivations, so believable that they feel like old friends. I'm currently thinking of the two guys at the bowling alley, straight out of a "Strange Brew" sketch going nowhere fast, "that about sums it up for me." (Lolz) But what about (Murray's brother) Buster choking on a meatball, the thankful little old lady trio, the poor old bum about to meet his maker, the proud music teacher, the doctor, the bartender's knowing looks, the groundhog!? And who can forget "Needle-nose Ned's" iconic scenes. Bing!It's hard not to fall in love with every single person in this cute little town. Am I right, am I right, or am I right?It's a delightful slice of one day in a small town, a fantasy, a romantic comedy, a celebration of life, and a call for continuous improvement all in one. Not bad for a popcorn movie, eh?

Review title: The kind of movie you can watch over and over again.
Review_body: Bill Murray does his best role ever. His type of persona fits his character to perfection. Basically this film is about a "jerk" who has is worst day of this life... for some reason just this day get stuck in a loop. Every morning he wakes up it's the same day, over and over again. No matter what he does he wakes up in his bed and it's the same day.Of course he is the only one that remembers the repeated days which makes him start to "experiment" in a way only Bill Murry can do.. (-What would you do if there was no tomorrow?) I would not be surprised if most of his dialogs are improvised.

This isn't a review but some words of admiration for a movies we all love. How all of us usually one time or other complains about our life being stuck into a routine and living the same day again & again,well our protagonist Mr.great bill Murray finds himself in the same situation here but in a more twisted way. The movie is so simple yet so genuinely funny especially when Murray tries to score some girls.This Film makes you wonder why there aren't movies like this anymore. Anyway the whole movie is great fun from start to finish and you can't help yourself but try to watch it again and again. You will not complain about the everyday routine the same way again.

Review title: A movie worth watching over and over again
Review_body: The main theme of the movie is repetition of a day in a simple town. It looks like there is nothing left to do, but the movie illustrates life perfectly, and as people start learning and improving themselves, their life becomes better and they become more likable. This is a movie that can really motivate the watcher to be a better person than he/she was a day before.The main character comes as grumpy and sarcastic, but in the end, he becomes a real artist, because he was motivated and led forward by love. Some things in life can't be achieved by forced repetition or mind hacking, but they depend on the internal values and self- confidence. This movie is a classic that is definitely worth watching a few times, as it represents different phases of life, from the lowest point, up to the total enlightenment.

One of my all time favorites. I love the story, active and settings. The message is a beauty; keep doing it over until you get it right. You're not leaving this day or the one meant for you until you own up to your calling, her calling.

Review title: Most underrated movie of all time
Review_body: Every once in a while all the elements of a movie will come together making it a great movie. Groundhog Day makes you laugh, makes you cry, makes you think. The only reason Groundhog Day originally received as much playtime as it did was because it was a generic "holiday" movie. It's played almost as many times on free TV as Bill Murry relives February 2nd. I, like many, watched it the first time just because it was there. Murry can forget Saturday Night Live fame, it's this cult-status movie that has made him. He's been in some good movies of late but has never been better than in Groundhog Day. In a fair world he'd have a Best Actor Oscar for this effort.

Review title: Best Flick Ever, had me ROTFL
Review_body: This movie was the most clever comedy ever written. The do-over style story telling just kept building with no climax in sight. I just could not focus on this whole film the first time because of the tears in my eyes. Bill Murray already was a great name to add to the cast. He has been a top A-list actor in several comedies and dramas up to the point of this flick. His deadpan approach to his character just brought a realistic scenario to the out-of-this-world story line. The cast selected balanced out his nonchalant personae just right. If I could give it 100 stars out of 10 I would. Not only will it be tough to beat this films comedy style, but it will be tough to cast someone as brilliant as Bill. Simply my favorite film ever.
Great romantic and very funny film you can watch over and over again

It is fascinating to watch a film with massive fame running before itself. Usually because you get the sense that your opinion on the film is of great importance, due to how people would view you afterwards. For a critic, this dilemma is routine. With this in mind, I am happy to announce that Groundhog Day somehow managed to not only fulfil my expectations, but also exceed them greatly. It is impressive how far a good script can carry a film. Although it is not the only thing worth crediting, I will not hesitate to say that the screenplay is the strongest asset this film has at its disposal. The film wields its characters and idyllic Pennsylvanian town with great strength and confidence, which it certainly should be. And the central concept of a day forever repeating itself works much better than I could ever have anticipated. It takes a mind to create an idea, but it takes a great mind to carry it to the finish line. 
And that is exactly what Danny Rubin and Harold Ramis did with this film. 
Well deserving of being credited a modern classic.

Review title: Truly living is about the joy of giving
Review_body: Movie that as a teen i found boring, but watched again today and i find it ahead of its time. It shows that life is really about living in the Now and about giving, just for the feeling of joy that you helped someone or make them feel better, without expecting anything in return. When you're happy in the present moment, life just flows.Andie MacDowell is just lovely.
Even if you do not realize, this movie is about you.

This movie is incredible. It is definitely my favorite movie of all time. It's one of those films that could not be pulled off by any other actor.... only Bill Murray could fit this role as Phil Conners, and he fits it perfectly. The incredible extent of his whimsical acting in this film is 80% of what makes it one of the greatest films I have ever seen... the other 20% belonging to the great storyline and supporting characters.This movie can be viewed at any time and still liked. It is a peaceful movie, if you are in relaxed spirits. It is especially great for those nights when you just got home from work or school and the day didn't go as you wanted it to, and you feel though as if life is struggle to no end. This movie is about second chances, and outside of the incredible humor, can be inspiring to get every day of your life right, and to remember the things that are most important in life.Watch it, and see what you think!
Without doubt my favourite movie. I must have watched it hundreds of times, as many times has Bill lived, and still love it.

Groundhog Day is work a work of marvelous comedy. This comedy exudes from the natural inclination to be humored by the hysterical facial expressions and the unfortunate situations Phil, Bill Murray, is placed in along the ride. It uses the somewhat mind boggling circumstance that the comical Bill Murray is stuck in time, and the situations involving romanticism, death, anarchy, and other natural human desires that may not be the best in certain situations. These experiences Phil finds himself creates not only just amusement and a reason to laugh, but also they make us think and feel for how we would've responded to such a phenomenon as defying space and time. Inspiring us with its progressive attitude of growth and morals, it makes us want to be better people and to mature, hopefully in a far less amount of time that repeating a single day hundreds of times. It exceeds in not just reaching those who want a good laugh, but also accomplishes speaking, through film, to those facing romantic struggles, depression, a weak will to live, and other such issues most humans experience throughout their lifetime. Though it did achieve a lot with such a small concept, related to humanities struggles, and gave us hope for a matured self, I could not reconcile the fact that Rita, Phil's love in the end (played by Andy McDowell), would settle for a man such as Phil. The movie also was vague, other than the fact that Phil had been a jerk and a prideful snob, about the reason that Phil had been sentenced to such a temporary fate as he was in Groundhog Day but it doesn't shed much light off of the great film that it is. It struts many of the great concepts of comedy that we all know and love and influences us to be better people. All in all, it is a stand-up movie that will not disappoint after a lazy night of movie-watching!

Groundhog Day, it's a movie we watched in film appreciation class. I personally think movies should contain certain theme and messages that we can observe. However, this movie's theme is not clear for me, and do not know what messages the director wants to give to the audiences. There were some few laughing points that entertained me, but it was more like a B class comedy film.

Groundhog Day used the formula of character + situation exceptionally. I got some good laughs with this movie but because it kept repeating and with only few changes by the middle of the movie it became quite tedious. The story was good and comical. I definitely recommend this movie.
I really enjoyed this movie! I suggest it to everyone

Review title: The movie show one guy's quality really.
Review_body: I just think it's not only a funny movie ,but also a special,wonderful one .We should thank Danny Rubin,the story writer ,who created a great script for this movie. Bill Murray did very well . When he knew he could live in this day all the time ,he did something that any guys would do: First,sex ; (very easy) Second,a lot of money; (not hard ) Third,a woman he love (very hard ) so,although he knew a lot of things about "Rita" ,but he found that the love of woman is very hard to get .In fact ,he understood something should be changed in himself ,and he should know himself , understand the value of people's life and even the meaning of true love .So, he tried to change himself ,and he did it in the end . From all of comments above ,we even can get a standard way of many guys ,they work very hard ,they earn money for fun or sex ,but they can't get true love of woman he love .It's so sarcastic,isn't it? 'Cause that need a big change in himself ,it's the most hard thing,nobody like change ,it's truth ,but they did it in the end just for true love of the woman. so,I think the movie show one guy's quality really.

Review title: Good, not as GREAT as I remembered.
Review_body: Its a good comedic situation, and explores even the human condition through repetition.But after seeing it without my nostalgia glasses... I realized, I'm not too fond of the message of the film.SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!! Don't read unless you've seen the movie.The ending has a hazy meaning / message. That Phil had to manipulate this woman to fall in love with him? I mean he had to also become the most amazing human being that ever existed... I would even say that makes her a bit shallow as well! I still enjoy it, but I'm just bothered by the ending now .If you've never seen it before though, it is DEFINITELY worth the watch!

When I was young I loved Groundhog Day because of Bill Murray, and all things Bill Murray were life to me. Every couple years I would watch it and it would reveal to me new things about life. This year I watched it, and as I basked in the glow of the amazing ending, I realized exactly why this film means so much to me. Why it is Harold Ramis' best work, and Bill Murray's best performance. It is about time, transformation, and the weather. It is about love, but it is also about becoming a person who truly loves others, and accepting oneself and circumstances beyond one's control to find happiness within. It's about the beauty of ice sculptures, and becoming unstuck in yourself.The thing to understand is that I never bought the ending of Charles Dickens' The Christmas Carol. I have never accepted Paul-on-the-road-to-Damascus, instantaneous conversion stories. My general experience has been: people's personalities tend to remain largely the same over time. So Ebenezer Scrooge's sudden overnight shift in personality was just not believable to me. In all adaptations of the Christmas Carol (including Scrooged, in which Bill Murray also plays the old miser), the happy ending and redeemed villain never landed for me. Through fear and regret imposed by supernatural entities, Scooge gets up on Christmas a new human being - seemingly having undergone a brain transplant with Sérgio de Mello. He's a rich philanthropist now, and brings joy to the hearts of children. All the work of one night. Huh. . . uh, no.But the transformation of Phil Connors in Groundhog Day lands for me. And the catharsis of this transformation and what it suggests about life is the heart of this film. The weatherman Phil Connors begins in the story as an egotist, a careerist, a condescending, bitter, sexist, and selfish person. But even here there is a note of promise: Phil admits to his love interest Rita (played with miraculous grace by Andie McDowell) that he doesn't like himself. Phil reluctantly goes to the Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania to cover the annual Groundhog Day festival, a task he considers beneath him. He despises the "hick" town and treats everyone with sarcasm or barely concealed contempt.When the time loop begins, Phil becomes trapped on February 2. Everyone else is now following the same deterministic path and time schedule and conversations as the "previous" day. The only variable is Phil himself - he has the agency to change the course of events, and he knows what is coming. The trouble is that each morning he wakes up in the bed and breakfast in Punxsutawney at 6:00 am to Sonny and Cher's "I Got You Babe" and all the actions have been reset. The only thing that is retained is Phil's memory and experiences.At first Phil is shocked, naturally. Soon he sees how powerful he is and begins taking advantage of people - thieving, seducing women, driving recklessly, and indulging a hedonistic lifestyle. But soon its clear that he really wants love - he learns everything he can about his producer Rita, and attempts to woo her. But each time she sees through his shallow maneuvers and into the emptyness of his soul. He becomes bereft, suicidal. He even kidnaps the groundhog itself and drives off a cliff to a fiery fate. But he cannot die: each time he ends his life he reawakens to February 2 once again. Trapped in a hellish limbo, a Nietzschean Eternal Return, Phil begins to slowly accept his fate.And then. By degrees and by experiences, Phil starts the miracle of transformation. The crucible of Groundhog Day has destroyed the old Phil and something new is emerging from the ashes. It begins with accepting that someone like him doesn't deserve Rita, as he is - she is a kind and loving person, and he is not. Slowly, Phil begins the process of being a better person through action. He helps strangers with their problems, saves lives, heals relationships, and betters himself by learning piano and ice sculpture. He begins to love the town of Punxsutawney and its inhabitants, not as means to end, but for themselves. And he does all this not in order to gain Rita's affections, but in order to finally accept himself.He also accepts his limitations. Phil is not a god: just as he cannot force Rita to love him, he cannot save everyone. He tries to save a homeless man in various ways from dying - but each day he fails. Phil may be trapped in immortality but he is not omnipotent.The movie never fully explains what caused the time loop or what caused it to end. There are various fan theories and speculations, and I actually prefer the ambiguity surrounding it. But I do like to think that what broke the loop was the final piece of Phil's metamorphosis. The moment he tells Rita next to her ice sculpture that, "No matter what happens tomorrow or for the rest of my life, I'm happy now. Because I love you." This sad scene always brings me near tears: Phil has accepted that this time and place are all he has, a brief candle to spend with Rita. But the key is that he has accepted himself and is happy with himself, as he is. He has become a person worthy of love. Rita, for her part, sees the good man that Phil actually is, and is drawn to him. He doesn't tell her about the time loop anymore, or try to win her by superficial means. He is honest and generous in his spirit.At that very moment, the weather changes for the first time in years (it's unclear how long Phil's been trapped, but probably about 40 years). This is the moment the loop breaks and Phil becomes unstuck in himself, in my opinion.He awakens the next day and it is February 3. Rita is beside him. Allow me to return briefly to Scrooge. When Scrooge awakens he throws open the window, rushes through town, furiously righting wrongs and deliriously trying to undo years of curmudgeonly behavior. But Phil Connors rushes to the window and sees the new day has come, and rushes back to bed with Rita. He asks her what he can do for her today. Here is the distinction: Phil is already a transformed man, a good man. He changed in just a day. . . one very long day. But we see through Bill Murray's incredible performance that this is the same man from the beginning, but transfigured. We saw the pain and tumultuousness of that transfiguration, like the changing of weather patterns. The blizzard has cleared and last and we see a blue sky. So we know this change is real and lasting. What's more, the last line of Groundhog Day is: "Let's live here."The miracle of Groundhog Day is not the supernatural time loop, or the ending of the time loop. There are no warnings from spirits of the past or future. It is always now in Groundhog Day. And the time for transformation is always in the now. The miracle of Groundhog Day is the transformation of one human being, and that is why it is one of my favorite films of all.

Groundhog day proves you don't need to rely on CGI explosions, fart gags or graphic sex to make an entertaining, classic movie. It's full of humanity and heart and genuinely winning performances and that's why it's so loved after all these years. I wish people would still fund midlevel movies like this!!!

Review title: Can be understood without knowing much background info on the holiday; but such info makes for a richer movie-watching experience.
Review_body: Groundhog Day is a holiday with deep roots in the pagan past. It is our only holiday whose theme is weather. It occurs at a time of year when weather occupies our thoughts more thoroughly than at any other time of the year. We know we're still stuck in winter, but enough of the winter has elapsed that we now feel justified in looking ahead to the promise of the spring equinox.More than any other holiday, Groundhog Day is the "looking-ahead" holiday. We're not so much celebrating the present on February 2 as we are a day in the not-too-distant future, the spring equinox (a very important time in the lives of ancient peoples). The spring equinox is simply being celebrated ahead of time, as Groundhog Day, on February 2. Asking us to bottle up our hopes until three weeks in March have passed would be be just plain unreasonable, right? This analysis helps explain all the talk of "forecasting" on Groundhog Day. But it isn't the Groundhog who's looking ahead, it is we. And whether it arrives early, late or on-time, this is one prediction that inevitably will prove true: spring will arrive, one way or another -- it always has. And on Groundhog Day we take solace in that fact.As I imply in my article, "Groundhog Day and the Groundhog Day Movie" the latter can be fully understood only in this context. Like the holiday itself, the "Groundhog Day" movie is all about transition. Sure, you can discern the transition without knowing much background at all about the holiday; but such knowledge improves the experience of watching the movie.Then again, "Groundhog Day" can be appreciated on many levels. Superficially, it can be enjoyed as a romantic comedy; Bill Murray makes it work on this level. But for those with a philosophical bent, it is a very profound movie. Some have even suggested a connection with Nietzsche's teaching of the Eternal Recurrence.

Review title: Like wine, it gets even better in time
Review_body:
I hated Bill Murray.... at first. Now Groundhog Day is one of my absolute favorites. It ticks like a precision watch. The human story is ingenious with mini dramas and steady evolution. Then we have brilliant sweet Andie MacDowell and neat performances by the other characters. The timing is razorsharp. Outdoor oompah music becomes fitting to the flow.
Like wine, this film gets better in time! I am glad it exists on bluray, so we don't have to wait for tv-reruns. In 2014 the one-day-timeloop theme was well used in the sf-movie Edge of Tomorrow with Tom Cruise.

Review title: Will your 3rd Feb. come? 60816 1101 Zhou Yuhan
Review_body:
Last Monday,I watched a film called Groundhog Day,which leaves me a deep impression on the fantasy and romance containing in it. Although released in 1993,the film has an incredible insight into life in 21st century. The hero Phil is played by Bill Murray,while Andie,the actress,characterizes Rita's features vividly. Directed by Harold Ramis,the film has won 6 wins and 17 nominations. You won't be regret to enjoy it.
 The story begins normally,a weatherman with his team is going to cover the annual Groundhog festivities in Punxsutawney. However,the arrogance inside Phil and the ordinary village become contradictory,which drives the next actions. Ironically,Phil finds out that he awakes at 6 every morning,and then,suffer from the same day, 2nd Feb. He cannot leave the town,nor commit a suicide. Sometimes tricks are played,to date a woman or make fun of others. Gradually,he fills himself by learning skills and helping people in need. Subtle changes eventually make him a better person. At last,Rita falls in love with this kind man and 3rd Feb. comes.
 Murray portray the role Phil in a particular way. When he realizes that he have to undertake the same day again,first he shows unbelievable,then there is curiosity and boredom. All of these,psychological actions are presented by Murray's gestures and facial expressions. Nevertheless,Rita's part is also attractive since she is the main point of Phil's life. The shift attitude of the supporting roles matters undoubtedly. In all,their acting performance is successful through the gradations.
 The film techniques are rather simple but meaningful. One repeated and classical shot is the 6:00 a.m. clock. The clock turns 6 and music begins,then we all know the same day misery happens again. More interestingly,because the film shoots repeated scene,every decorations and locations of actors must be accurately right. I suppose that was a tolerant.
 The first theme is apparent,which teaches us to treasure and to be a good person.And the second one is my own assumption. In contemporary life,many people live exhaustedly and numbly,have nothing changed,thus no passion for life and their 3rd Feb. never comes. They just live one day for a thousand times,instead of living a thousand days for themselves. This is quite alarming,and makes us rethink.
 Many successes are mentioned,though the repeated plots seem to be a little boring. In conclusion,this is a movie that suits lovers and friends at weekend. I will give six stars out of ten. 
 3180104970 Zhou Yuhan

What would happen to "you" if you were to live the same day over, and over, and over again? Would you go mad? Or, would you indulge yourself in drinking, eating and sleeping? You would not only live the same day over and over again but you would be endowed with immortality. Even if you commit suicide, you will wake up the same morning, intact and unharmed. Could you fall in love? What would be the point of living? You would memorize everything that will happen on that particular day. You would know what time, who would be where and for what reason. Perhaps, that is what life is - the uncertainty principle that makes us live. You wouldn't need any money for anything. Very clever film and one of Murray's best performance - highly recommended.

This movie changed my life in an hour... Well personally it didn't because I love my life, but definitely could change someone's' life. It shows how you can appreciate every little moment of your life and how this moment can be so vital and catalytic for the rest of your day or for your remaining existence in this world. Also how can you play a very vital role in someone else's life. There is no such thing as fate. Everything is in your hand, in your mind and in your actions. It's never to late to do anything. Learn something new like an art eg. Piano or Sculpture or how to talk to people and to make them feel better about them selves and about you if you are interested. Make your choices for the best outcome you can get, not because you have to.
